results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows snippets of family life while at play, at birthday celebrations and on holiday. We see the family drive across the bridge to Phillip Island and enjoy swimming and canoeing at the beach there. The reel also includes scenes of caravan camping, koalas and a trip to the war memorial at Mount Macedon. The family enjoy games of tennis, ball games and swings and roundabouts at a playground. The film includes good examples of fashion, Austin cars and recreational activities of the time.

Originally made using 9.5mm film.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)

00:01:37:00 children with their dad in the water at the beach (good example of bathing fashion)
00:02:58:00 tennis match between mum and dad
00:04:29:00 car with caravan and family in bush camp setting
00:05:14:00 Austin car with family standing at the front talking and combing hair
00:05:58:00 children being pushed on swings in a park by their mother (good fashion and sunglasses references)
00:7:30:00 close-up of little girl’s face as she blows out her birthday candles and looks to camera
00:07:41:00 family in front of war memorial at Mount Macedon
00:08:36:00 steam train travelling on a country rail line
00:08:46:00 family looking out from a ferry window
00:08:52:00 kids on a roundabout at a playground
00:09:00:00 grandmother, mother and children sitting on a playground wall – the grandmother is shooting a water pistol.
00:09:08:00 children on playground roundabout and dad jumps on to join them
00:09:32:00 a koala sitting in a tree climbs to the top and looks down
00:09:45:00 family and friends stand in front of a picket fence (good example of family groups and fashion from the time)
00:10:01:00 wide shot as cars travel across the bridge to Phillip Island

00:10:14:00 POV from inside car as it drives over the Phillip Island bridge

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Macao, China and Hong Kong in the 1960s. The quality of the film can be challenging at times (shaky, sometimes dark and damaged) but it is well worth it for scenes of the busy waterways and street life around Hong Kong Island, Kowloon and Macau. Billy particularly focuses on the many different watercraft such as passenger and cargo ships, ferries, row boats, houseboats and plenty of wonderful traditional junks.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:46:00 scenes filmed from a train as it travels past cultivated fields, farmers, bullock teams, field hands
00:01:25:00 traditional house by as river
00:01:19:00 young children working on logs at a timber mill
00:02:12:00 field workers closer to the camera
00:02:30:00 small, covered junks on the water in a harbour
00:02:45:00 busy port
00:03:05:00 large group of moored, small house boats with mountains in the background
00:03:22:00 children playing on a beach
00:03:50:00 ferries and traditional sailing boats as well as large ships
00:04:29:00 large ferry
00:04:55:00 traditional junk sailing by a large modern ship
00:05:45:00 city residential apartment buildings with mountains in background.
00:06:18:00 city streets, shops and signs, including one for ‘Coca Cola’
00:08:07:00 new and old watercraft
00:08:75:00 colourful passenger ferry
00:08:35:00 lovely traditional junk in full sail
00:09:30:00 a child points at the camera while playing with friends
00:10:00:00 international shipping
00:10:30:00 wonderful striped canvas tent bathing boxes followed by scenes of locals relaxing at the beach.
00:12:52:00 another notable traditional junk sailing by the camera
00:14:11:00 vegetable sellers in low lying boats

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 37]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film shows some wonderful car racing in Victoria and South Australia in 1953 and 1955. Includes the Templestowe and Rob Roy hill climbs, races at Altona and Baxter Park, and the Grand Prix at Port Wakefield.

While some footage is overexposed there are good scenes of the cars and spectators. Drivers shown include Jack Brabham, Reg Hunt, Kevin Neal and Doug Whiteford. Brabham is shown winning the 1955 Australian Grand Prix.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list

00:00:10 ‘Why the hurry fellows’ title card

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 5: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is part two of two and is titled ‘Innes National Park’, and contains scenes from the Park, located in South Australia, including the rolling wavy sea viewed from rocky cliff tops of the park coastline, the dunes, wildflowers and beach tracks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Innes National Park’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:55:00 campsite including an open fire with ‘billycan’, and a tarpaulin being set up as cover.
00:04:07:00 sign for ‘Innes National Park’
00:04:27:00 sign for ‘Shell Beach’
00:06:15:00 shifting sands in a dune.
00:08:04:00 sign for ‘The Gap’
00:08:51:00 ‘Inneston’ sign
00:10:36:00 ‘Stenhouse Bay’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Orchid Isle’, is the second of two parts capturing the filmmaker’s travels in Fiji. Wallace films townships, harbours and local buildings in the thatched Fijian style. He also captures some tourist attractions such as the capital city of Fiji - Suva, Fijian performers and lush garden walks.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 4: Part 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film, titled ‘Fascinating Fiji’, contains scenes of Fiji landscapes, towns and resorts. The filmmaker takes footage from a vehicle so that the scenes change with his travels. Much of the reel is taken up with scenic vistas of roadside crops, lush greenery, trees and flowers, hills in the distance and the sea.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 35]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film follows the club meetings of the ‘Victorian Sporting Car Cub’, in 1956 to Fisherman’s Bend and Albert Park in Melbourne, Templestowe in outer Melbourne and Hepburn Springs in regional Victoria. Cars are are regular feature in Kenneth’s films and this film certainly shows viewers many wonderful models from the era. The film inlcudes Reg Hunt who would become one of Australia’s best racing car drivers.

Among the racing audiences we see Mrs Rankine, daughter Bettye Rankine and her husband Bob Wootton, with their young son watching the races and having a car-side picnic.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:10:00 title card ‘For Some Real “Hurry Up” Join the Vic. Sporting Car Club’
00:00:22:00 program brochure for ‘Fisherman’s Bend Classic Airstrip Races’ followed by cars rounding a bank of hay bales
00:

00:00:00:00

00:04:17:00 onlookers in grass at Fishermen’s Bend.
00:00:47:00 brochure for the Hepburn Hill Climb 1956.
00:08:15:00 brochure for Moomba Motor Races.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

In this film, the filmmaker shows life on and around the beach at Anglesea in Victoria - walking, hang gliding, surfing, motoring in the dunes and on the sand, taking in the views from the cliffs. Wallace focuses on examples of coastal wildflowers as well as animal life where he finds it.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:06:46:00 hikers in the dunes.
00:11:00:00 a large snake in a tree.
00:11:25:00 hang gliding off the cliffs.
00:13:28:00 walkers on the beach.
00:15:23:00 a crab in the shallows.
00:16:04:00 surfing.
00:18:54:00 a jeep pulling a stuck ‘Holden’ station wagon car from the sand.
00:19:30:00 women looking over the view from the dunes.
00:19:54:00 a ‘jeep’ vehicle charging up a steep dune track.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film, titled ‘Arnhem Land’, contains scenes from a trip to Arnhem Land and Katherine in the Northern Territory in the 1970s.

Travel is by jeep on dusty roads, boats and walking. Wallace captures the varied landscapes of rivers, rocky outcrops, hills, trees, flowers and the scrub as well as termite mounds. He also films buffalo, lizards and waterbirds. A highlight is the Aboriginal rock art drawings throughout the film.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’ and ‘Arnhem Land Safari’
00:01:08:00 sign for the township of Katherine in the Northern Territory.
00:02:05:00 truck travels along a dirt road with scrub burning-off on either side.
00:02:29:00 truck travelling crossing a river.
00:02:48:00 pictorial map of the Jim Jim Falls area.
00:03:28:00 canvas tents at a campsite.
00:06:55:00 four wheel drive and trailer.
00:07:52:00 water buffalo.
00:08:00:00 very large bird in equally large nest at the top of a tree.
00:14:30:00 sign ‘Northern Territory Administration Aboriginal Reserve’.
00:13:45:00 examples of Aboriginal rock art drawings which appear until the end of the reel.
00:24:50:00 swimsuits of the era while swimming in a river.
00:27:00:00 digging a tourist bus out of a sandy track.
00:28:58:00 skeletal remains in the mouth of a cave.
